title: Hawaii Big Island faces Tropical Storm Hone – NBC10 Philadelphia
message:
Tropical Storm Hone is expected to whip gusts and drop rain on the southern edges of Hawaii this weekend, potentially inflicting flooding and wind damage on the Big Island and raising the risk of wildfires on the drier sides of the islands.
The National Weather Service has issued a tropical storm warning for Hawaii County, which includes all of the Big Island and a red flag warning for the leeward sides of all islands.
Here is the latest information on Tropical Storm Hone.
It's expected to become a Category 1 hurricane for a 12-hour period on Sunday but will likely be past the Big Island by that point, said Laura Farris, a weather service meteorologist in Honolulu.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.

title: Hawaii Big Island is under a tropical storm warning as Hone approaches with rain and wind
message:
HONOLULU — Tropical Storm Hone drew near Hawaii on Saturday with gusts of wind and heavy rain that could cause flooding on the Big Island while raising the risk of wildfires on the islands' drier sides.
A tropical storm warning was in effect for the Big Island, and a red flag fire warning was issued for the leeward sides of all islands through 6 p.m. on Saturday.
While Hone presents high fire dangers, “it’s not on the magnitude of that,” weather service meteorologist Derek Wroe in Honolulu said Saturday.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.
Gilma may bring rain to Hawaii but it's not clear how much, said Laura Farris, a weather service meteorologist in Honolulu.

title: Hawaii Big Island is under a tropical storm warning as Hone approaches with rain and wind
message:
Recommended VideosA tropical storm warning was in effect for the Big Island, and a red flag fire warning was issued for the leeward sides of all islands through 6 p.m. on Saturday.
The National Weather Service issues the alert when warm temperatures, very low humidity and stronger winds combine to raise fire dangers.
Firefighters remained on the scene of a small blaze that started Friday night in Waikoloa, on the dry side of the Big Island, according to Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth.
Officials were closing some Big Island beach parks in anticipation of dangerously high surf and preparing to open shelters if needed, he added.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.

title: Hawaii Big Island under tropical storm warning as Hone nears southern edges | Hawaii
message:
Tropical Storm Hone was approaching the southern edges of Hawaii on Saturday with gusts of wind and heavy rain, potentially inflicting flooding and wind damage on the Big Island over the weekend and raising the risk of wildfires on the drier sides of the islands.
The National Weather Service has issued a tropical storm warning for Hawaii county, which includes all of the Big Island, and a red-flag warning for the leeward sides of all islands.
Hone, which means “sweet and soft” in Hawaiian and is pronounced “ho-nay”, had top winds of 65mph (105km/h) early on Saturday.
It will likely strengthen into a category 1 hurricane as it passes near or south of the Big Island from Saturday night into early Sunday, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
The eastern and south-eastern parts of the Big Island could get 5-10in (11-25cm) of rain.

title: Hawaii Tropical Storm Warning As Hone Nears
message:
The National Weather Service has issued a tropical storm warning for Hawaii County, which includes all of the Big Island, and a red flag warning for the leeward sides of all islands.
Hone, which means "sweet and soft” in Hawaiian, had top winds of 65 mph (105 kph) early Saturday.
The Hawaii Tourism Authority told travelers it's still safe to come to the islands but recommended that people postpone outdoor activities.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.
The weather service's red flag warning will be in effect from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Saturday.

The National Weather Service issues the alert when warm temperatures, very low humidity and stronger winds combine to raise fire dangers.
Firefighters remained on the scene of a small blaze that started Friday night in Waikoloa, on the dry side of the Big Island, according to Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth.
Officials were closing some Big Island beach parks in anticipation of dangerously high surf and preparing to open shelters if needed, he added.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.

title: Hawaii Big Island under tropical storm warning as Hone approaches with rain , wind
message:
Tropical Storm Hone was approaching the southern edges of Hawaii on Saturday with gusts of wind and heavy rain, potentially inflicting flooding and wind damage on the Big Island over the weekend and raising the risk of wildfires on the drier sides of the islands.
The National Weather Service has issued a tropical storm warning for Hawaii County, which includes all of the Big Island, and a red flag warning for the leeward sides of all islands.
Hone, which means "sweet and soft" in Hawaiian, had top winds of 65 mph (105 kph) early Saturday.
It will likely strengthen into a Category 1 hurricane as it passes near or south of the Big Island from Saturday night into early Sunday, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.

title: Tropical Storm Hone forecast to bring strong winds and heavy rain to Hawaii
message:
HONOLULU (AP) — Tropical Storm Hone is expected to deliver strong winds and heavy rain to Hawaii this weekend, particularly to the Big Island and Maui, as it passes south of the island chain.
A tropical storm watch was in effect Friday for Hawaii County, which includes all of the Big Island, according to the Central Pacific Hurricane Center in Honolulu.
It was moving west at 16 mph (26 kph) with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph).
The U.S. Drought Monitor says much of Hawaii is in moderate drought while parts of Maui and the Big Island are in extreme drought.
The weather service issued a red flag warning at the time, something it does when warm temperatures, very low humidity, and strong winds combine to raise fire danger.

title: Tropical Storm Hone Forecast to Bring Strong Winds and Heavy Rain to Hawaii This Weekend
message:
HONOLULU—Tropical Storm Hone was expected to deliver strong winds and heavy rain to Hawaii this weekend, particularly to the Big Island and Maui, as it passes south of the island chain.
A tropical storm watch was in effect Friday for Hawaii County, which includes all of the Big Island, according to the Central Pacific Hurricane Center in Honolulu.
The U.S. Drought Monitor says much of the state is in moderate drought, while parts of Maui and the Big Island are in extreme drought.
The weather service issued a red flag warning at the time, something it does when warm temperatures, very low humidity and strong winds combine to raise fire danger.
But forecasters said the Category 2 hurricane would likely weaken to a tropical depression by Wednesday as it got closer to the Big Island.

title: Tropical Storm Hone threatens Hawaii with fire and floods
message:
A tropical storm warning has been issued for Hawaii’s Big Island with the storm on track to pass close to the state this weekend.
“Tropical storm conditions are expected in the warning area as early as Saturday afternoon and continuing into Sunday,” the National Hurricane Center said in its 8 p.m. HST advisory.
It has maximum sustained winds of 50 mph, with tropical storm winds extending outward up to 115 miles from the center, the National Hurricane Center said.
The storm is forecast to pass about 150 miles south of the Big Island late Saturday into Sunday morning.
The system will weaken as it approaches Hawaii, but whatever remains of it could take a swipe at the state late next week.

title: Tropical Storm Warning for Hawaii as Hone impacts just hours away
message:

title: Stunning East Coast tourist hotspot is SINKING amid  perfect storm  of threats
message:
One of America's most visited cities is under threat of vanishing underwater due to rising sea levels and more frequent violent storms.
'This is essentially the water level expected during a coastal storm, Peter Girardi, VP of Climate Central, tells the DailyMail.com.
'These places are most at-risk from coastal flooding, and likely even more vulnerable as land subsides.'
By 2150, the Bay Street Viaduct Area and Savannah Historic District are going to be fully inundated by any coastal storm surge.
But as hurricane season ramps up and flood risks grow, the people of coastal Georgia know they can't afford to be complacent.

title: AccuWeather predicts  dramatic surge  in storms to close hurricane season
message:
Some meteorologists believe the Atlantic Ocean could see a “dramatic surge” in severe storms in September, possibly with anywhere from six to 10 tropical storms.
That rate would be similar to the record-breaking 2020 hurricane season that saw 10 September storms, according to AccuWeather meteorologists.
Alex DaSilva, AccuWeather’s lead hurricane expert, said a shift in weather patterns would push out dry, dusty air that tamped down most tropical weather in recent months.
“I think things could get very active potentially very quickly here as soon as that dry air goes away,” DaSilva said, “We could see a parade of storms.”The Atlantic hurricane season peaks Sept. 10, according to AccuWeather.
However, plentiful warm water could fuel tropical storms and hurricanes into the fall.

title: One - third of Canadians report being personally impacted by severe weather : poll | iNFOnews
message:
Vernon News One-third of Canadians report being personally impacted by severe weather: pollThe Don River overflows causing flooding on surrounding roads following heavy rain in Toronto, on July 16, 2024.
A new poll suggests more Canadians are feeling the direct impacts of extreme weather, but that has not changed overall opinions about climate change.
When Leger asked the same question in June 2023, around one in four Canadians indicated they had been impacted by extreme weather.
Despite all that, people who took the survey were less likely to be concerned about climate change now than in 2023.
About half of respondents believe there is still time to reverse climate change, while just over one-third said it's too late to turn back the clock.

title: Cox declares state of emergency over flash flooding in Utah
message:
Spencer Cox declared a state of emergency on Friday in response to recent flash flooding events that have impacted communities across the state this month.
"The flooding we have seen over the past few weeks has been devastating," the governor said in a statement.
"I saw some of the damages firsthand in Sanpete County, and I know Utahns have been similarly impacted across the state."
Flooding has also been reported at times on streets and in slot canyons throughout the state this month.
That, in turn, has led to "significant damage to homes and public infrastructure," state officials said.

title: $3 . 7m project completed with Japan help
message:
The UNDP has successfully completed the $3.7 million project 'Strengthening Tsunami and Earthquake Preparedness in Coastal Areas of Pakistan' with the support of the Japanese government.
According to a press release issued on Friday, the projected was completed in partnership with the Economic Affairs Division and the PDMAs of Sindh and Balochistan.
Through the project, the UNDP addressed a critical development challenge in the coastal districts of Malir, West/Keamari in Karachi, and Gwadar by reducing tsunami risks and their potential impact on the coastal communities in Pakistan.

title: B . C . wildfire crews move to  mop - up  stage but drought conditions continue
message:
The BC Wildfire Service says the Shetland Creek wildfire, which had triggered evacuation orders and alerts in the southern Interior since it was first detected on July 12, is now classified as “being held” at about 280 square kilometres in size.
Story continues below advertisementThe service says many fires are in the “mop-up” stage, when crews move in to douse the edges of a blaze with water in order to fully contain it.
It says dry conditions continue to contribute to the fire risk in northern B.C.
Just under 100 of B.C.’s active blazes are classified as burning out of control.
Campfires continue to be prohibited with the exception of the Prince George Fire Centre, the Haida Gwaii Forest District and the northwestern corner of B.C.

title: Tropical Storm Hone will be at Big Island doorstep tonight ; you only have till midday to make last - minute prep : Big Island Now
message:

People also remembered Hurricane/Tropical Storm Iselle in 2014, which made landfall in Puna as a strong tropical storm and did plenty of damage.

title: Watch : Wildfires rage in parched southeast Brazil
message:
Sao Paulo: Wildfires spread across Brazil's most populous state of Sao Paulo Friday, prompting highest-level alerts in 30 cities and filling the capital's skies with smoke.
Low humidity and temperatures topping 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit) were exacerbating fire conditions in the southeast region, which is facing a prolonged drought.
The Sao Paulo state government set up a crisis cabinet Friday night to coordinate work on battling the flames.
Meanwhile, the state's eponymous capital Sao Paulo was covered by a dense gray fog.
"Fires emit dense and toxic smoke that harms the environment and human health, causing problems to the respiratory system and cardiovascular disorders," it added.

title: $3 . 7m project for disaster preparedness completed - Newspaper
message:
ISLAMABAD: The Uni­ted Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has successfully completed a $3.7 million project to strengthen disaster preparedness and response in coastal areas and reduce tsunami risks and their potential impact on coastal communities in Pakistan.
The project, named Streng­then­ing Tsunami and Ear­th­­quake Pre­pared­­ness in Coastal Areas of Pakistan, was completed in partnership with the Economic Affairs Division and PDMAs in Sindh and Balo­chistan, and supported by Japan.
The coastal project’s success in strengthening disaster preparedness and response has laid a foundation for continued resilience in the coastal communities in the country.
This was achieved through the revision of guidelines for earthquake and tsunami preparedness and improving the disaster response system and preparedness capacity of vulnerable coastal communities.
The project also prioritised gender equity in its approach to mitigate coastal hazards.

title: Ahead of Tropical Storm Hone , HNN takes a look at previous storms that impacted Hawaii
message:
Ahead of the severe weather, the HNN First Alert Weather team looked back on previous storms that have impacted the island chain.
Tropical Storm Hone is the first storm to receive a Hawaiian name since Ema during the 2019 season.
The last storm to make landfall on the Big Island was Tropical Storm Iselle in August 2014.
Tropical Storm Hone’s forecasted path is similar to that of Tropical Storm Iselle.
Please make sure to be prepared ahead of this weekend and stay tuned to the First Alert Weather team for the latest updates.

title: Tropical Storm Hone prompts warnings for Hawaii Big Island
message:
A satellite view of the weather system from tropical storm Hone near Hawaii's Big Island on Friday.
Tropical Storm Hone swirled closer to Hawaii’s Big Island on Saturday with maximum sustained winds of 65 mph, forecasters said.
Tropical Storm Hone is forecast to pass near or south of the island Saturday night into early Sunday, the National Hurricane Center said.
A tropical storm warning was issued for Hawaii County, and swells could cause life-threatening surf and rip currents across the island chain on Saturday, the agency said.
Residents on Hawaii’s Big Island could see 5 to 10 inches of rain, the hurricane center said in Saturday advisory.

title: Today in History : Hurricane Andrew devastates South Florida - WSVN 7News | Miami News , Weather , Sports
message:
(WSVN) - Thirty-two years ago, Hurricane Andrew, a Category 5 storm, slammed into South Florida, leaving a trail of devastation across Miami-Dade, Broward, and Monroe counties.
The powerful hurricane claimed 65 lives and caused more than $26 billion in damage across Florida, Louisiana and the Bahamas.
Before Hurricane Katrina, the 1992 storm was the costliest natural disaster in U.S. history.
Andrew made landfall near Homestead with winds around 165 mph, flattening homes, uprooting trees, and knocking out power for weeks.
It caused unforgettable destruction and was a turning point that changed everything from hurricane forecasting to building codes.

title: Governor Cox declares State of Emergency due to recent flooding
message:

“The flooding we have seen over the past few weeks has been devastating,” said Gov.
In the release by Governor Cox, the recent wildfire burn scars and high temperatures have increased the risk of flood flesh and debris flow damaging structures.
The executive order is effective immediately and will remain in effect for 30 days, unless Legislature were to extend the state of emergency.

title: ENC residents concerned over the amount of flooding seen with heavy rain events
message:

The state tells me it belongs to the town, and now the town is telling me it belongs to the state.

title: Nicobar project will not disturb or displace tribes : Environment Minister Bhupendra Yadav
message:
The development of a port and airport in the pristine Nicobar islands “will not disturb or displace” any of the Shompen, one of the indigenous, vulnerable tribes native to the island, according to Environment Minister Bhupendra Yadav.
‘Revoke clearances’Mr. Ramesh had written to Mr. Yadav on August 10, demanding that all environmental clearances accorded to the project be revoked.
The project, Mr. Ramesh said, was coming up in an earthquake-prone zone that had seen the ground shift by 15 feet during the 2004 tsunami.
Quake-prone islandsSeismologists opine that an earthquake of the magnitude (9.2 on the Richter scale) that had generated a tsunami in 2004 would likely occur again only after 420 to 750 years, Mr. Yadav said.
The Nicobar Islands project will be developed over 30 years in a “phased” manner and the number of trees expected to be felled would likely be “half” of what was estimated, the Environment Minister claimed.

title: Disaster preparedness sales tax holiday underway
message:
SARASOTA, Fla. (WWSB) - If you didn’t stock up on storm supplies this year, or maybe ran low after the wrath of Hurricane Debby, the state of Florida is lending a helping hand.
Saturday kicked off the states second Disaster Preparedness Sales Tax Holiday this year.
Unti September 6th, residents can purchase severe weather basics like batteries, flashlights, smoke and carbon monoxide detectors and portable generators sales tax free.
The measure was passed by the Florida Legislature, and signed into law by Governor Ron DeSantis to help people stay prepared ahead of storm season.
At Home Depot off University Parkway in Sarasota, shoppers were greeted with signs outside promoting the savings opportunity.

title: Earthquake alert system coming to Nevada using network of 300 seismic monitors
message:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Thousands of people in the Las Vegas Valley reported feeling an earthquake last week.
Seismic monitors run by the Nevada Seismological Laboratory are being used for California alerts.
The lab has 300 seismic monitors across the state and eastern parts of California.
Many of the seismic monitors are on mountain tops tied to a wildfire camera network.
Thanks to seismic monitors, last week people in Southern California got a 10 second heads up on their phones before a quake.

title: Unusually early cold storm could dust California Sierra Nevada peaks with rare August snow
message:
Parts of Highway 89 through Lassen Volcanic National Park in California were closed Saturday after an estimated three inches of snow fell overnight, according to the National Weather Service.
Photos posted by the National Weather Service and local authorities showed a white-covered peak from Rainier and a dusting of snow at Minaret Vista, a lookout point southeast of Yosemite National Park in California's Sierra Nevada.
Madera County Deputy Sheriff Larry Rich said it was “definitely unexpected” to see snow at Minaret Vista in August.
More light snow was possible in California on the crest of the Sierra Nevada, mostly around Tioga Pass and higher elevations of Yosemite National Park, the National Weather Service said.
But it is usually closed much of each year by winter snow that can take one or two months to clear.

title: What to know about getting Florida hurricane supplies without sales tax
message:
The holiday periods, which will allow people to avoid paying sales taxes on purchases, are part of a tax package that lawmakers and Gov.
The state also held a similar tax holiday around the June 1 start of the six-month hurricane season.
Also, the state will hold what has been dubbed the “tool time” tax holiday from Sept. 1 through Sept. 7 to provide tax breaks on tools and work gear such as gloves, boots and ladders.
Meteorological experts have forecast an above-average hurricane season this year, which could mean more than 20 named storms before the end of November.
The tax holiday starting Saturday and the similar period around the start of hurricane season are projected to trim $80.2 million from state and local tax revenues.

title: Residents in Camden County neighborhood experience flooding as heavy rain moves through area
message:
KINGSLAND, Ga. – Residents in a Camden County neighborhood are experiencing flooding roadways as heavy rain moves through the area.
On Thursday and Friday, the street was flooded and the water went all the way to their front door.
They set up sandbags to help with the flooding.
A family in Camden County setup sandbags to help with flooding.
I had to pick up my daughter on Thursday and Friday.”They said they’re unsure where the water goes and there’s a retention pond in the neighborhood, but residents said it overflowed during Tropical Storm Debby.

title: CenterPoint Energy : Hosts Community Open House at the West Gray Metropolitan Multi - Service Center on Saturday , August 24
message:
Houston - Aug. 24, 2024 - This Saturday, August 24, from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., CenterPoint Energy will host a community open house event in Houston, TX.
"We have heard the calls for change, and we are taking action now," said CenterPoint President and CEO Jason Wells.
Schedule & LocationThe location and schedule for the next open house is as follows: Saturday, August 24, 2024, at the Metropolitan Multi-Service Center, 1475 W Gray St., Houston, TX.
CenterPoint has doubled its vegetation management workforce in order to remove higher-risk vegetation near power lines by August 31.
Installed automated devices: CenterPoint has installed more than 300 automated devices, known as trip savers.

title: Wyevale nurseries begin construction of new sustainable resevoir
message:
Wyevale Nurseries is forming the new water conservation system at its Container Tree division on King’s Acre Road, to help capture, store, and recycle water.
A reservoir was previously constructed in 2022, which Wyevale said helped to not only attract new species of wildlife to the area but helped to decrease the risk of flooding and increase the amounts of recycled water in the area.
Tim Fawbert, group finance director at Wyevale Nurseries said they were working “diligently” to ensure sustainability and environmental targets were being met.
"Additionally, ponds with good water quality can help to mitigate against climate change by sequestering carbon.
“Ponds help to retain water on the nursery too, which has benefits as a water source for pollinators, irrigation and for natural flood management.

title: Hawaii on alert for Tropical Storm Hone , extreme heat travels across country - WEIS | Local & Area News , Sports , & Weather
message:
ABC News(NEW YORK) — Hawaii is on alert for Tropical Storm Hone while extreme heat is expected to expand from the South to the Midwest, leaving 25 million Americans under heat alerts this weekend.
A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Big Island of Hawaii as Tropical Storm Hone passes by to the south of the islands.
In terms of wind, tropical storm force winds are forecast to begin this evening and throughout the overnight hours into Sunday morning.
Gusts will generally be in the 25 to 40 mph range, but there could be some gusts of over 50 mph in some of the higher elevations on the Big Island.
The extreme heat drifts north over the next few days, heading through the central plains and into the upper Midwest.

title: ABC - National News - Xtra 99 . 1 FM - Today Hits and Yesterday Favorites
message:
A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Big Island of Hawaii as Tropical Storm Hone passes by to the south of the islands.
While it won’t be a direct hit, the storm is still close enough to deliver some potentially dangerous impacts.
The main threat is for heavy rain that could cause flash flooding and landslides, especially on the eastern side of the Big Island where rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches are possible.
In terms of wind, tropical storm force winds are forecast to begin this evening and throughout the overnight hours into Sunday morning.
Gusts will generally be in the 25 to 40 mph range, but there could be some gusts of over 50 mph in some of the higher elevations on the Big Island.

title: Hawaii on alert for Tropical Storm Hone , extreme heat travels across country
message:
(NEW YORK) — Hawaii is on alert for Tropical Storm Hone while extreme heat is expected to expand from the South to the Midwest, leaving 25 million Americans under heat alerts this weekend.
A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Big Island of Hawaii as Tropical Storm Hone passes by to the south of the islands.
In terms of wind, tropical storm force winds are forecast to begin this evening and throughout the overnight hours into Sunday morning.
Hone may reach hurricane status for a short period of time as it passes south of Hawaii, but it is forecast to stay over open water and eventually weaken back into a Tropical Storm.
The extreme heat drifts north over the next few days, heading through the central plains and into the upper Midwest.

title: Tropical storm Hone strengthens , approaches Big Island
message:
HONOLULU (KHON2) — Tropical Storm Hone is intensifying as it approaches the Big Island of Hawaii, prompting a Tropical Storm Warning for Hawaii County.
The National Weather Service (NWS) has issued a Tropical Storm Warning for Hawaii County, indicating that tropical storm conditions are expected within 36 hours.
‘Take this seriously,’ officials urge ahead of Hone impactsTropical-storm-force winds extend up to 115 miles from the center of the storm.
Key hazards include:Wind: Tropical storm conditions are anticipated to begin this evening on the Big Island, with the strongest winds expected downslope of higher terrain, over headlands, and through passes.

message:
However, the hurricane center has identified four tropical waves in the Atlantic Ocean that warrant monitoring as we approach the peak of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.
Tropical wave 1: A tropical wave is in the eastern Atlantic Ocean just offshore the west coast of Africa, moving west.
Tropical wave 2: A tropical wave is in the Atlantic Ocean approaching the Lesser Antilles, moving west.
Tropical wave 3: A tropical wave is in the central Caribbean Sea southward to Panama is moving west.
Tropical wave 4: A tropical wave has moved into the Bay of Campeche, moving west.

title: Deadly Wildfires Ravage Southern Sao Paulo State in Brazil
message:
In a tragic turn of events, wildfires in Brazil's southern Sao Paulo state have resulted in the deaths of at least two individuals, as confirmed by officials on Saturday.
A total of 36 cities in the state have been put on high alert as the fires continue to spread.
Sao Paulo Governor Tarcísio de Freitas announced that both local and federal authorities are intensifying their efforts to combat the flames.
The fires have primarily affected regions outside the city of Sao Paulo, one of Latin America's largest urban areas, home to over 11 million people.
Despite the city of Sao Paulo largely escaping the direct impact of the fires, dramatic footage on social media shows smoke-filled skies and burning trees in rural areas along highways.

title: The 2014 Napa quake is still taking its toll
message:
The 6.0 force in the West Napa Fault jolted the city and especially Browns Valley extraordinarily.
While the epicenter started a few miles north of American Canyon, the seismic energy through the city of Napa and West Napa was horrendous.
The 2000 5.0 Napa earthquake couldn’t shake a leg (pardon the pun) to the 2014 late August night shaker.
As an architect, one thing I check initially when starting any Napa project is the earthquake fault maps for Napa.
There are over eight known and ‘inferred’ fault lines with ample setbacks in West Napa that start and stop abruptly.

title: Montreal - area mayors say Quebec government has not delivered on promised flood relief
message:
The Communauté métropolitaine de Montréal (CMM), which represents 82 municipalities, says there has been no meaningful change to the program if sewer backups located far from waterways are not included.
People living on certain streets have been told they're eligible for financial aid, he said, while residents of other streets have been told they're out of luck.
But the site also says homeowners are only eligible for assistance for sewer backups "if a nearby waterway overflowed."
Alain Mailhot, a professor of urban hydrology at Quebec's national scientific research institute, said it doesn't make sense to compensate people for sewer backups only if they live close to a river.
In a press release, the group requested that sewer backups caused by "urban runoff" during episodes of heavy rain be eligible for government aid.

title: Unusually early cold storm could dust California Sierra Nevada peaks with rare August snow – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
Parts of Highway 89 through Lassen Volcanic National Park in California were closed Saturday after an estimated three inches of snow fell overnight, according to the National Weather Service.
It snowed overnight on Mammoth Mountain, a ski destination in California, with the National Weather Service warning hikers and campers to prepare for slick roads.
But it is usually closed much of each year by winter snow that can take one or two months to clear.

title: B . C . wildfires trending into the  held  and mop - up stages
message:
The BC Wildfire Service says the Shetland Creek wildfire, which had triggered evacuation orders and alerts in the southern Interior since it was first detected on July 12, is now classified as “being held” at about 280 square kilometres in size.
The service says many fires are in the “mop-up” stage, when crews move in to douse the edges of a blaze with water in order to fully contain it.
Still, it says recent rainfall has not been enough to alleviate severe drought across many areas of the province, and it’s still an active wildfire season.
Just under 100 of B.C.’s active blazes are classified as burning out of control.
Campfires continue to be prohibited with the exception of the Prince George Fire Centre, the Haida Gwaii Forest District and the northwestern corner of B.C.

title: Vietnam facing global weather disruptions due to La Nina
message:
Meteorologists attribute these changes to the transition from El Nino to La Nina, indicating the onset of a neutral El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) state.
La Nina represents the opposite phase, involving the cooling of the same oceanic region, though the frequency of its occurrence can vary.
The probability of La Nina occurring is estimated at 55-65 per cent.
"La Nina is expected to impact Vietnam between September and November 2024, coinciding with the typhoon season in the central region.
However, the global atmospheric system's disruption during the transition from El Nino to ENSO and La Nina is affecting Vietnam, leading to recent abnormal rainfall and flooding.

title: UN warns of high risk of flooding in Somalia
message:
MOGADISHU, Aug. 24 (Xinhua) -- Several communities in Somalia are at imminent risk of flooding as river levels continue to rise in central parts of the country, a UN agency warned in a flood advisory issued Saturday.
Projections by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and the Somalia Water and Land Information Management (FAO-SWALIM) indicate a risk of flash floods and riverine floods despite the absence of rain in Somalia and eastern parts of Ethiopia.
The FAO-SWALIM also said after the river level at BeledWeyne steadily dropped from the bank-full level in May, a slow upward trend began in July.
"The river level consistently rose thereafter, but was relatively stable and below the moderate flood risk level in July and only crossed the moderate flood risk level on Aug. 8," said the FAO-SWALIM in its flood advisory released in Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia.
The FAO-SWALIM called for the activation of evacuation plans, warning that there is a high risk of riverine flooding in Beledweyne, Bulo Burte, Jalalaqsi, Jowhar, and Balcad districts and other surrounding areas.

title: Arizona woman missing after Grand Canyon flash flood , officials say – NBC 6 South Florida
message:
Search and rescue crews at Grand Canyon National Park were looking Friday for an Arizona woman who has been missing since she was swept into a creek during a flash flood, while the National Guard has been called in to help evacuate other stranded hikers.
The woman was hiking in Havasu Creek, about a half-mile (800 meters) from where it meets up with the Colorado River, when the flash flood struck around 1:30 p.m. Thursday.
She was identified as 33-year-old Chenoa Nickerson of Gilbert, Arizona, the National Park Service said Friday.
She had stayed overnight at a campground near the village of Supai on the Havasupai reservation, deep in a gorge off the Grand Canyon.
Katie Hobbs activated the Arizona National Guard late Friday, including Blackhawk helicopters, to help evacuate hikers from the village.

title: About Lily Toy Box , an organization that provides toys to Houston - area children
message:
Stroud’s foundation, as the star quarterback’s organization teamed up with Lily’s Toy Box to hand out gifts to Houston-area kids.
Stroud’s charitable efforts obviously made headlines, but Lily’s Toy Box has been a noble provider in the Houston community for years now, and the organization’s beginnings go back to one of the lowest points in the city’s history.
After hearing on the news that hundreds of children would lose their toys due to flooding and evacuations, Lily decided to give her own toys away.
Lily’s mother posted on Facebook, seeking toy donations from others, and suddenly, Lily’s living room was filled with toys donated for Houston’s kids.
Lily’s Toy Box has helped provide toys for Houston’s kids ever since, coming up big during catastrophic events like the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Extreme weather takes a big toll
message:
It provides valuable data needed to get state and federal reimbursements but disguises the deeply personal impact of extreme weather, the reality that behind every picture of destruction is a person or family or community whose lives have been upended.
That’s not to say that cataloging and better understanding the number of billion-dollar extreme weather events is not important.
A major part of the toll of a storm is the trauma it creates in its victims, and trauma has a long tail.
Thinking about the personal toll of extreme weather should increase our urgency to take the needed steps both large and small to minimize it.
Part of it is the long game of making big adaptations to reduce the intensity and frequency of extreme weather.

title: Where are the Hurricanes ?
message:
SARASOTA, Fla. (WWSB) - It was hyped as a very active Hurricane Season, and the second half could still be.
The August forecast dropped to only a 48% chance of La Niña developing in September.
Sunspots2 (Station)In a research paper titled “Evidence linking solar variability with US hurricanes” (published in the International Journal of Climatology), Robert E. Hodges and James B. Elsner from Florida State University found a link between the number of sunspots to the number of hurricanes in a year.
In the Introduction of the article, they state:“…increased solar activity – associated with more sunspots – means more UV radiation reaching the Earth’s upper atmosphere.

title: It shouldve been done a long time ago : Viewers get help for tree debris piling up since Derecho
message:
A viewer told us her Northside neighborhood had debris still piled up not only from Beryl, but also the Derecho storm that happened back in May.
“It should’ve been done a long time ago,” Lauren Peña said, referring to a huge pile of storm debris not being picked up outside of her mother’s Bucan street home.
The Peñas aren’t the only ones in their neighborhood that sits between I-45 and the Hardy Toll Road dealing with this problem.
Just driving there, KPRC 2′s Deven Clarke saw dozens of other big debris piles.
They also sent us this map of the area with green dots they say represent loads that have been collected.

title: Unusually early cold storm could dust California Sierra Nevada peaks with rare August snow
message:
Parts of Highway 89 through Lassen Volcanic National Park in California were closed Saturday after an estimated three inches of snow fell overnight, according to the National Weather Service.
Photos posted by the National Weather Service and local authorities showed a white-covered peak from Rainier and a dusting of snow at Minaret Vista, a lookout point southeast of Yosemite National Park in California's Sierra Nevada.
It snowed overnight on Mammoth Mountain, a ski destination in California, with the National Weather Service warning hikers and campers to prepare for slick roads.
More light snow was possible in California on the crest of the Sierra Nevada, mostly around Tioga Pass and higher elevations of Yosemite National Park, the National Weather Service said.
But it is usually closed much of each year by winter snow that can take one or two months to clear.
